Some changes in commander seem to prevent arming when external sensors come online late. I'm currently tracking this down.

QGC displays the error message "Preflight checks complete, reboot before arming." A reboot, obviously, doesn't fix the issue.

Also, the issue isn't reported back to GCS, so the failure reporting is broken too.

@pavel-kirienko

title: Lidar via PWM stopped working, needs a reset to get it going
body: Not sure at which point it broke

title: Special handling for manual control inputs for large heading errors
body:
As soon as the heading error becomes large (often the case for VTOL in high winds) the manual roll and pitch controls do not lead to the reaction the user would expect. This is because the roll and pitch sequence comes after the yaw sequence in the euler formulation we are using (we are generating the attitude setpoint quaternion from euler angles).
However, this is tricky for the user and should be fixed.

title: Clamp manual yaw target when system is in yaw rate limit
body:
In this log the yaw tracking is really good:
http://logs.uaventure.com/view/xM8RPz26NeFtmcR8Cnm5RL#A_YawRate_PLOT

But the system response felt sluggish. This is most likely because a yaw setpoint was built up as the system was hitting the 60 deg/s yaw rate limit and so the quad continued to turn after the yaw set point.

title: Level calibration issue
body: If the board rotation parameters are non-zero the algorithm does not wait for the horizon to settle after the parameters have been zeroed. Either we wait or we don't zero them and just consider them in the final result.

title: Revisit git submodule magic
body:
We need to look into the git submodule magic because there are some corner cases where data can get lost. One of the cases is when files are added in a submodule but not committed.

Example steps to replicate:

```
echo FOO > Tools/jMAVSim/new_file.txt
(cd Tools/jMAVSim && git add new_file.txt)
make clean
make
```

title: simulator: fix mavlink parsing of sim+RC stream
body:
The mavlink stream from the simulator and the mavlink stream over serial
(used for RC input) both had the same MAVLINK_COMM channel and were
therefore sharing an internal buffer in mavlink_parse_char. This meant
that most (low rate) serial messages were getting swallowed by the high
rate simulator stream.

This change fixes the issue where RC input was not properly arriving in
Gazebo, however it breaks the `commander takeoff` command in SITL which
needs to be investigated.

title: Mission: Takeoff then Waypoint, vehicle skips takeoff location
body:
- Run from QGC with master SITL
- Load mission file
- Send to vehicle
- Back to Fly view
- Change flight mode to Mission
- Arm

Two problems:
- At the point you change the flight mode to Mission the vehicle sends an error level mavlink message about takeoff. This happens before you arm.
- When you arm, the vehicle takes off and heads in the direction between the two waypoints. The at some point it changes trajectory towards the final waypoint, skipping the takeoff waypoint entirely.

If you run a mission with just a single takeoff item it works correctly and the vehicle flies to the takeoff location.

[TakeoffBug.px4.mission.txt](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/files/52738/TakeoffBug.px4.mission.txt)

However, we were able to arm and fly the quad, not sure if this should be possible. The commander only locks arming down if the above mentioned flag is set, otherwise no battery check is performed (except avionics on arming): https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/commander/commander.cpp#L1886

title: Numerical errors in `get_rot_matrix()`
body:
While debugging the sensor validation issue I found out that [`get_rot_matrix()`](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/16b6b3caa2e152888bc942dbe723cfab3320d526/src/lib/conversion/rotation.cpp#L43-L51) may be subject to some significant numerical errors. For example, the identity matrix it returns looks like this:

```
1.000, 0.000, -0.025,
0.000, 1.000, 0.011,
0.025, -0.011, 1.000
```

While close to identity, it still introduces visible errors when applied to a three dimensional sensor sample (mag in this case):

``` python
>>> m=numpy.array([[1.000, 0.000, -0.025], [0.000, 1.000, 0.011], [0.025, -0.011, 1.000]])
>>> [math.degrees(x) for x in tf.transformations.euler_from_matrix(m)]
[-0.6302281562617439, -1.4320961841646465, 0.0]
>>> m.dot([0.143555, -0.0184021, 0.561035])
array([ 0.12952912, -0.01223072,  0.5648263 ])
```

title: UAVCAN ESC enumeration must ignore all non-ESC nodes
body:
Currently it sends begin enumeration requests even to nodes that are not ESC:

```
uavcan fw srv: UAVCAN ESC enumeration: sent Begin request
uavcan fw srv: UAVCAN ESC enumeration: begin request for node 125 timed out.
```

Node 125 in the log above is Zubax GNSS, it is not enumerable.

title: UAVCAN parameter bridge loses exactly one parameter
body:
@bendyer  The issue could also be caused by QGC, but that is much less likely.

I have tested on two different kinds of nodes, Zubax GNSS and PX4ESC. The former has 19 configuration parameters, but QGC lists only 18 (`gnss.warn_sats` is missing). The latter has 37 configuration parameters, but QGC lists only 36 (`light_index` is missing).

title: Parameter saving logic in UAVCAN bridge is flawed
UAVCAN parameter bridge shall not assume that every connected node implements configuration services
Check CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_XXXXX constructs
body:
The cmake conversion did not propagate the following 

ARCHDEFINES += -DCONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_$(CONFIG_BOARD) 

While this should be OK as long as we maintain our defconfig files (by hand) to ALWAYS have CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_XXXXX (make oldconfig will break this, and I have to hand merge) it may be good to visit all the #if CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_XXXXX constructs and ensure a compile time failure will result if missing.

title: UAVCAN mag - failsafe/calibration issues
body:
# Issue 1:

The UAVCAN mag isn't getting properly switched over to when it comes up later. "Best" equals 1, the UAVCAN mag, but it isn't getting used.

Voter class output right after boot :

```
nsh> attitude_estimator_q status
...
attitude_estimator_q: mag status:
INFO  validator: best: 1, prev best: 0, failsafe: NO (# 0)
INFO  sensor #0, prio: 50
INFO    val:   0.0914, lp:   0.0917 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0010 conf:   1.0000
INFO    val:   0.4205, lp:   0.4205 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0013 conf:   1.0000
INFO    val:   0.3210, lp:   0.3208 mean dev:   0.0000 RMS:   0.0013 conf:   1.0000
INFO  sensor #1, prio: 75
INFO    val:   0.5176, lp:   0.5176 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0002 conf:   1.0000
INFO    val:  -0.2025, lp:  -0.2025 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0002 conf:   1.0000
INFO    val:   0.2537, lp:   0.2537 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0004 conf:   1.0000
INFO  sensor #2, prio: 75
INFO    val:   0.5176, lp:   0.5176 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0002 conf:   1.0000
INFO    val:  -0.2025, lp:  -0.2025 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0002 conf:   1.0000
INFO    val:   0.2537, lp:   0.2537 mean dev:  -0.0000 RMS:   0.0004 conf:   1.0000
```

If I connect via QGC, suddenly I see "SENSOR FAILSAFE: RETURN TO LAND IMMEDIATELY". I'm not sure yet what the correlation is to connecting to QGC.
# Issue 2:

The next issue is that magnetometer calibrations don't stay. After calibration, the system goes to standby, but on reboot, it again fails to start up properly.
Note that there is not proper error message related to a missing calibration or similar, just that ARMING_STATE_INIT to ARMING_STATE_STANDBY is denied if I try to arm it.

Note : I have main board orientation set to YAW_270 and external mag orientation set to default (YAW_NONE)

@pavel-kirienko @LorenzMeier Help would be appreciated on this one.

title: Position control with GPS and Optical Flow
do not set position setpoint too early
body: This makes sure that the position setpoint for position hold is only set once the velocity of the vehicle has sank under the provided limits. Without this fix the vehicle was always going back to the point where the user had the sticks centered.

title: Line calculation for POSCTL, convergence north/south
body:
@tumbili as discussed

I've observed this previously but didn't follow up on it (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/2299). When testing variations on runway takeoff we also used the same calculation to draw a line with current heading. It resulted in a wrong actual heading during takeoff:

![screen shot 2015-10-21 at 08 47 56](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5750020/10768340/debad4d4-7ce0-11e5-963d-50cabaf7f6b5.jpg)

The blue lines were calculated by the posctl method, the red line is were it actually should be. Note that both lines match for 90 degrees.

Example calculations (posctl method):

```
Origin: 47.389492,8.0317354

160:
Point behind:
47.389492 - cos(160degrees) * 100/1e6 = 47.3895859693
8.0317354 - sin(160degrees) * 100/1e6 = 8.03170119799

Point ahead:
47.389492 + cos(160degrees) * 3100/1e6 = 47.3865789529
8.0317354 + sin(160degrees) * 3100/1e6 = 8.03279566244

90:
Point behind:
47.389492 - cos(90degrees) * 100/1e6 = 47.389492
8.0317354 - sin(90degrees) * 100/1e6 = 8.0316354

Point ahead:
47.389492 + cos(90degrees) * 3100/1e6 = 47.389492
8.0317354 + sin(90degrees) * 3100/1e6 = 8.0348354
```

Solution:
The calculation we actually want can be found here (great circle distance): http://www.movable-type.co.uk/scripts/latlong.html (part "Destination point given distance and bearing from start point")

We can update posctl to do the following:
- calculate the 2 waypoints with bearing and constant distance (a few hundred m)
- before we reach it, calculate new actual bearing at the end of the line
- use the new bearing for the next pair of waypoints

title: Code stability in air on master

milestone.title: Release v1.1.0
milestone.description: This release should add functionality currently held back like the unified sensor fault detection facility and delta angles for the EKF.

body:
@tumbili Unfortunately it looks like we have a stability issue which is isolated to fixed wing aircraft on master.

I suspect the stack size of the EKF estimator. I have adjusted it downward recently after intensely reviewing in-flight stack usage. But its possible there is a code path that I missed during that review. We need to come up with an approach to reproduce this on the bench.

title: EKF not fully reliable

milestone.title: Release v1.1.0
milestone.description: This release should add functionality currently held back like the unified sensor fault detection facility and delta angles for the EKF.

body:
Yesterday we have done some hover tests where we wanted to tune mc_pos_control for altitude and position. We flew with master 0fed23a and we chery-picked EKF fix https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/2968. 
The fix itself works as before it, our LPOS_Z was totally different then baro signal, and it was causing way too much CPU load. Now the load dropped down to ~25% for us, and EKF performance is much better, but still not as good as before pulling the https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/2815#event-413847903. 

Note: We had quite bad GPS signal yesterday, but it was pretty much the same for all the tests. 
The main issues are sudden jumps/spikes in the position setpoint, and the fact that position setpoint rises although throttle stick is in or below the deadzone - basically we had a situation that aircraft was rising a couple of meters up while throttle stick was at zero (http://logs.uaventure.com/view/ekETmDV6hEsFNhENV7CAkA! - unfortunately logmuncher does not display rc inputs - I think we have some naming mismatch), ergo estimator does not work properly.

Below are two snaps showing the spikes and lpos not fully following baro:
![alt_ekffix](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13371589/10507692/89514978-7322-11e5-8b5d-60bdb8125b96.png)
![baro_ekffix](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13371589/10507691/89510fd0-7322-11e5-8987-2c9ca0159dd6.png)
(http://logs.uaventure.com/view/WPiHd9TEXGvyGoSjZgidkh)

Then we switched to the branch with old version of EKF and its performance was far more reliable (pilot finally had control in altitude control), although not fully perfect due to bad gps signal. But the difference has been significant. 
(http://logs.uaventure.com/view/gNoRJNsCHftMQ6pAJcFgn7)
![alt_oldekf](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13371589/10508342/c2afbc5a-7326-11e5-9ec2-d934b814dffa.png)
![baro_oldekf](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13371589/10508343/c2b10880-7326-11e5-90c5-08e0e8fbcc3d.png)

body:
If I have sensor-level HIL enabled the HUD values "twitch" heavily when the plane sits still. The values spike to impossible values as soon as the plane starts moving. Almost like all the values are scaled by a large factor.

I can't say when this could have been introduced, had a long break from HIL. QGC version doesn't seem to matter (same with 2.7.1 and master).

title: multirotor SITL: wrong mag values subscribed
body:
The wrong mag values are selected in the voting in the attitude_estimator_q in multirotor SITL.

It seems that the priority of MAG 1 is higher than MAG 0, therefore the mag topic 1 instead of 0 is subscribed which is all 0.

I'm not quite sure at what level this should be fixed or worked around. I assume the mag topic 1 has higher priority because it generally refers to the external mag? Where is this sensor priority (respectively uORB) priority encoded?

```
WARNING: degenerate accel / mag! (file Firmware/src/modules/attitude_estimator_q/attitude_estimator_q_main.cpp line 334)
```

title: UAVCAN time synchronization is broken

milestone.title: Release v1.8.0
milestone.description: Maintenance release

body:
## The context

Certain peripheral device that is currently being equipped with UAVCAN required that the FMU and the device itself ran synchronized clocks. UAVCAN does support time synchronization over the CAN bus, and so does libuavcan ([spec](http://uavcan.org/Specification/6._Application_level_functions/#time-synchronization), [tutorial](http://uavcan.org/Implementations/Libuavcan/Tutorials/6._Time_synchronization)). The PR https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/2895 has extended the UAVCAN driver with time synchronization feature, at the same time breaking UAVCAN sensors (https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/2912, https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/2911).
## The problem

Obviously, in order for the sensor fusion to function correctly, all sensor measurements must be timestamped using the same (or synchronized) time source. This condition used to be easy to meet, since all sensor drivers were simply using HRT. This changed when a time synchronization master was added to the UAVCAN driver, because the library now uses a dedicated hardware timer (namely TIM5), which runs with a phase offset of about a second (didn't measure it exactly) with respect to the HRT, and incoming UAVCAN messages are timestamped by the library incorrectly using this time source. These incorrect timestamps are then copied further to ORB sensor topics.

A temporary solution has been introduced (see https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/2914), in which the UAVCAN driver simply uses HRT instead of the library's provided timestamps, which is NOT a proper solution and provides degraded timestamping precision.
## Solutions
#### Use HRT instead of TIM5 for libuavcan

This is the easy way, but it has a significant drawback: _since HRT must be be monotonic, it cannot be synchronized with other time sources_, because that would require it to change rate and/or jump.

Do we care about use cases where PX4 has to synchronize its time with an external time source, e.g. a companion computer or a GNSS receiver? I expect that we do.
#### Use TIM5 for timestamping everywhere

This approach permits to maintain monotonicity of HRT, adding another clock which can change rate in order to maintain synchronization with an external source.

The current code will have to be updated in order to use the new, synchronized clock for timestamping instead of HRT. Also, the developers will have to keep in mind the difference between monotonic clock and synchronized clock, and why they are not interchangeable.

FYI, grepping the codebase for `hrt_absolute_time` shows 464 matches.
#### Extend HRT with synchronized clock

From application-level standpoint this solution is identical to the previous one, the difference is in implementation - instead of using a dedicated hardware timer for synchronized clock, the HRT driver can be extended with notions of _phase offset_ and _rate offset_ between monotonic and synchronized clocks. By the way, this is how monotonic/synchronized clocks are implemented in STM32 and LPC11C24 drivers for libuavcan. Sources: [STM32 ](https://github.com/UAVCAN/libuavcan/blob/master/libuavcan_drivers/stm32/driver/src/uc_stm32_clock.cpp), [LPC11C24](https://github.com/UAVCAN/libuavcan/blob/master/libuavcan_drivers/lpc11c24/driver/src/clock.cpp).

@davids5 @mhkabir @LorenzMeier

title: With perm_stab off, attitude setpoint during back transition with standard VTOL is 0
body:
This essentially means that during the back transition there is no stabilization and practically no manual control. If the user doesn't do anything, the VTOL will keep the rates is has and continue that movement during the back transition time until multirotor kicks in.

See first back transition here: http://dash.oznet.ch/view/bgJVKEGhAtkcwqsRd46KE7
![screen shot 2015-08-19 at 16 48 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5750020/9359644/6ea32536-4692-11e5-9f53-7c6429d9b350.png)

title: Battery current for MAVLink is not scaled correctly

milestone.title: First beta release
milestone.description: The first beta release is intended for early adopters and testers. It should have a limited but stable feature set and cover the basic, but important use cases. It can be rough around the edges but must not fail or be hard to use.

body:
@LorenzMeier 
Apart from hardware issues discussed [here](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/px4users/bI1-ZbecoN8), there is also software bug. Yesterday we noticed that we don't get a current reading via MAVLink but it is logged correctly. To be more precise, the current reading we got over MAVLink was 0 or 1.

In https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/0e26c2b37b362c19d30f0544ed6d21bc408bcd7d/src/modules/mavlink/mavlink_messages.cpp#L550 and https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/0e26c2b37b362c19d30f0544ed6d21bc408bcd7d/src/modules/mavlink/mavlink_messages.cpp#L575 the battery current for MAVLink get's divided by 10. The target field is uint16. According to specs it's supposed to contain milliamps \* 10. This suggests that the source field contains milliamps, but as far as I can tell it actually contains amps. This would match the effect we saw for currents between 0 and 15 amps.

The scaling for the MAVLink message changed during the last commit.

title: FMUv1  does not show voltage (stable)
body:
The battery voltage does not work anymore on FMUv1 (stable branch).

The ADC channel is read in https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/sensors/sensors.cpp#L1709 but the voltage read is 0.01v to 0.02v and garbage. It's not a param scaling issue.

The FMU is used on an IO and the battery port is connected.

title: Multicopter position control: Attitude control oscillation
body:
Summarising some comments from @SimonWilks here:

Logs:
http://dash.oznet.ch/view/SHgcgQZ7wcLX9DQV6B7pMU
http://dash.oznet.ch/view/n6psxmgeH3EXg4JntrPH6M

The trigger is the combined low-then-high throttle event, which leaves the system for some time without effective attitude control:
http://dash.oznet.ch/view/SHgcgQZ7wcLX9DQV6B7pMU#Thrust_PLOT

I suspect this code path could play a role in this, as its defeating the new safety built into the mixer. We probably should completely remote it, as it can lead to a loss of attitude control.
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/mc_pos_control/mc_pos_control_main.cpp#L1204-L1212

title: UAVCAN broken in stable / master

milestone.title: First beta release
milestone.description: The first beta release is intended for early adopters and testers. It should have a limited but stable feature set and cover the basic, but important use cases. It can be rough around the edges but must not fail or be hard to use.

title: uORB multi pubsub depends on order of subscribing/publishing
body:
Below is what I found, correct me if I'm just wrong :):

Basically, I think, in the current multi pubsub implementation, the publisher needs to be started before the subscriber, otherwise they won't talk to each other.

An example from #2297 would be:
1. Mavlink starts first and wants to subscribe to the distance_sensor topic. It gets the first instance here:
   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/uORB/uORB.cpp#L144
2. The the ll40ls wants to do a advertise_multi:
   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/drivers/ll40ls/LidarLitePWM.cpp#L116
   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/uORB/uORB.cpp#L93
   I believe this fails here:
   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/uORB/uORBManager_nuttx.cpp#L246
   And gets +1 here probably:
   https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/uORB/uORBDevices_nuttx.cpp#L471
3. This leads to mavlink subscribing on 0 and the ll40ls publishing on 1.

Instead of the check ...
- Does the node exist already?

It should be something like:
- Does the node exist already and has stuff been published yet?
- Does the node exist already but is it only opened by a subscriber?

title: pca8574 not compiled
body:
The pca8574 driver is currently not compiled in but it is nevertheless in the startup script:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/2625d3e973d9fcd06474278c5cf5ae2cd70ddeaf/ROMFS/px4fmu_common/init.d/rcS#L104

Is this on purpose?

title: Gimbal attitude control in fixed-wing mode not useable
body:
We're using actuator output group 2 in the FW attitude controller: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/fw_att_control/fw_att_control_main.cpp#L1094
That and the gimbal app fight each other..

title: IO doesn't load if mixer file has 8 outputs
body:
Maybe related to https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/2093

IO fails if the mixer has 8 outputs assigned, this happens on start:

```
[px4io] mixer send error -1
mixer: error loading mixers from /etc/mixers/AERT.main.mix: Operation not permitted
[i] Error loading mixer: /etc/mixers/AERT.main.mix
```

title: 8th chanel on mix-file does freeze the whole sbus-output
body:
First at all - my configuration works very well and i am very happy with it. 

I use the actual PX4 master-dev-build from April 25th. 

There I recognized a very strange issue. 
All the sbus out chanels work great, but as soon as I adress the chanel 8, the whole servo-ouput freezes. 

Here the setup on my *.mix file, that does work fine: 
### 
# NG1 Rev2 Aerodynamics - Delta-wing and Rudder mixer for PX4FMU

This file defines mixers suitable for controlling a delta wing aircraft with rudder using PX4FMU.
## Elevon left left CH 1

Differential roll more up, less pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -7500  -2500      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1   4000   4000      0 -10000  10000
## Elevon left middle CH 2

less roll, more pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -4000  -4000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1   8000   8000      0 -10000  10000
## Elevon right right CH 3

Differential roll more up, less pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -2500  -7500      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1  -4000  -4000      0 -10000  10000
## Elevon right middle CH 4

less roll, more pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -4000  -4000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1  -8000  -8000      0 -10000  10000
## Rudder mixer CH 5

Thix mixer enables Rudder for manual yaw-steering  

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 2  10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
## Airbrake CH 6 

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 4  10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
## Motor speed mixer CH 7

Channel group 0, channels 3 (thrust) is passed directly through to the output.

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 3      0  20000 -10000 -10000  10000
### 

so far so good, 

As soon as I ad an 8th chanel, the whole sbus output is jamed, all servos freezes to their extreme positition
### 
# NG1 Rev2 Aerodynamics - Delta-wing and Rudder mixer for PX4FMU

This file defines mixers suitable for controlling a delta wing aircraft with rudder using PX4FMU.
## Elevon left left CH 1

Differential roll more up, less pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -7500  -2500      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1   4000   4000      0 -10000  10000
## Elevon left middle CH 2

less roll, more pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -4000  -4000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1   8000   8000      0 -10000  10000
## Elevon right right CH 3

Differential roll more up, less pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -2500  -7500      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1  -4000  -4000      0 -10000  10000
## Elevon right middle CH 4

less roll, more pitch

M: 2
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 0  -4000  -4000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 1  -8000  -8000      0 -10000  10000
## Rudder mixer CH 5

Thix mixer enables Rudder for manual yaw-steering  

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 2  10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
## Airbrake CH 6 

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 4  10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
## Motor speed mixer CH 7

Channel group 0, channels 3 (thrust) is passed directly through to the output.

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 3      0  20000 -10000 -10000  10000
## Parachute CH 8 

M: 1
O:      10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
S: 0 2  10000  10000      0 -10000  10000
### 

And it doesnt help wheter I change the source of chanel 8 (I tried everything - to take RC aux1 from control group 3, or Flaps from Control Group 0 or what ever), I tried also without connected servos on sbus chanel 8. No luck. 

So there I am with my analysis and think, this must be a bug. 

Best wishes
Severin

title: Offboard Position Control: Not setting the velocity ignore flags makes controller cut throttle: offboard velocity setpoints do not work
body: See https://github.com/mavlink/mavros/issues/273#issuecomment-93316957

title: Altitude hold (currently POSCTL) should prioritize altitude over speed

milestone.title: First beta release
milestone.description: The first beta release is intended for early adopters and testers. It should have a limited but stable feature set and cover the basic, but important use cases. It can be rough around the edges but must not fail or be hard to use.

body: As I recall, the last time I tested POSCTL for fixedwing I had the issue that commanded speed had priority over commanded altitude. So if it was not able to hold the speed it would start to dive. IMHO that's wrong, priority should be to hold the altitude.

title: Mag calibration crashes
Mavlink receiver: fix attitude sp logic
body: Port https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/1920 to mavlink receiver

title: Random mavros_attctl errors on SITL CI
body:
This seems to be related to a timing issue with MAVROS and publishing attitude and throttle. Sometimes I see the same timestamps for alternating attitude_setpoints (att/thrust).

Will try to fix it with the next SITL demo test update

title: Offboard velocity setpoints broken on master
body:
We have reports that https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/1786 introduced a regression that disables offboard velocity setpoints.

More tests are needed.

title: Multiplatform position control: recheck gains and verify if all parameters are read in correctly
SITL installation script: drcsim installation fails on ubuntu
body: @AndreasAntener  Can you maybe give this a test when you run the installation anyway for some reason? It's not high priority though.

title: Fix hardfault in the uavcan module
body:
A kind of smoking gun was found over there https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/1711. tl;dr uavcan process segfaults when it receives an ESC status message from the CAN bus, but works reliably if optimization level is lowered.

Possible cause is a race condition somewhere in the CAN driver.

title: nuttx-bringup: multicopter: motors won't spin
body:
@davids5 This needs more investigation. I flashed the nuttx-bringup branch onto a pixhawk on a multicopter. I can arm but the motors won't spin if I throttle up. It seems that the controller is running correctly and publishing meaningful data to the actuator controls uorb topic.

Is this a known issue or do you wan't me to investigate further? (E.g. look at pwm output, mixer, ...)

title: Inspect side-effects of disabling stack checking
body:
This includes #1691. @davids5 @sjwilks These are the combined symptoms of disabling stack checking:
- V1: microSD mount fails
- V3: USB serial link (NuttX) is started, but never registers with the host (device doesn't list under /dev/tty.usb*)

I'm not 100% sure yet if this is timing or if we're missing something, but we clearly don't have everything under control yet.

title: Gazebo simulator: investigate why the outdoor world does not launch on ubuntu
body:
The outdoor_world currently seems to work on arch linux only. empty_world works fine on all systems.

Symptoms: gazebo starts but can't find some model files, shows a black screen

This issue is in this repo because my guess is that something in the setup script is wrong.

title: UAVCAN clean target still not operational
body:
Just got this, and for me its a bit head vs. wall - I've tried a bunch of things on this already. I presume its a wrong path in the dependency files, and probably stems from how uavcan hooks into the build system. Neither clean / distclean are currently operational.

@davids5 any insights?

title: Fix issues discovered by Coverity
body:
See https://scan.coverity.com/projects/3966 - the latest analysis has been run on a combined build Firmware+NuttX; some issues look quite suspicious.

This blocks https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/1660, because some of the discovered issues can be the cause of the crashes described there.

This wiki page describes how to submit a build to Coverity: https://pixhawk.org/dev/configuring_coverity_scan_cross_build
